Award.AwardTitle: Flexoelectric Strain Gradient Sensors- a New Sensing Technology for In-situ Structure Health Monitoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
1068345
Xiaoning Jiang
North Carolina State University

The objective of this research is to research a sensing technology based on a flexoelectricity (FE) concept, capable of capturing strain gradient information with great sensitivity. This project is to design and develop a new class of strain gradient sensor (SGS) that can detect damage at a very early stage and in-situ monitor the damage initiation and progression. This FE-microstructure sensor enables ultra-sensitive sensing of strain gradient which is most sensitive measurand near the localized damage location. Motivated by recent progress on FE structure and microfabrication the proposed efforts will, for the first time, design, fabricate, and characterize the flexoelectric microstructures for strain gradient sensing.

The research to be undertaken consists of three major tasks including fabrication of FE microstructures, material tailoring and characterization of FE microstructures, design and prototype SGS devices. This study will lay the groundwork for a new class of strain gradient sensor (SGS) with high strain gradient sensitivity, low signal to noise ratio and broad bandwidth. The proposed work will significantly advance scientific and engineering knowledge in the area of structure damage sensing technology and greatly enhance the capability of early damage detection and in-situ health monitoring of nation's infrastructure systems. A corresponding education and outreach program involving women and minority students is developed and integrated with the planned research program. The planned collaboration with NASA centers and Boeing through test plan development will promote the integration of academic research with industrial participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied flexoelectric materials, structures and sensing devices for structural health monitoring.

We first studied the fundamental flexoelectric properties in ferroelectric materials from the direct and reverse aspects. High-permittivity materials, such as BaxSr1-xTiO3 (BST), were found to have much larger flexoelectric properties compared with other solid materials. Micro-cantilever, micro-pyramid and thin film structures were fabricated and characterized using a self-developed flexoelectricity characterization equipment. In order to study the flexoelectric performance of the material at different size scales, we measured the coefficient of microcantilevers with different thicknesses ranging from 1.4 mm to 30 μm. A consistent coefficient of 8.5 μC/m for all the specimen were observed. It implies that electrical energy density and sensing ability of flexoelectric micro-cantilevers are superior to those of their piezoelectric counterparts.  Two micro-pyramid arrays were also prepared with feature sizes at 10 μm level for converse flexoelectricity characterization. An electric voltage was applied across the micro-pyramid to generate an electric field gradient and the induced mechanical strain was monitored by the Doppler laser vibrometer. The results confirmed the scale effect of flexoelectric microstructures. The identical measurement method was used to estimate the shear flexoelectric coefficient of BST ceramic and the results matched well with the theoretical expectation. Furthermore, bottom-up method was employed to fabricate nano size flexoelectric structure. A 130 nm thick BST thin film was grown on a silicon wafer by RF magnetron sputtering technique. The flexoelectric coefficients of the prepared thin films were, for the first time, determined experimentally. It was revealed that the thin films possessed a transverse flexoelectric coefficient of 24.5 μC/m at Curie temperature (28 ?) and 17.44 μC/m at 41?. The measured flexoelectric coefficients are comparable to that of bulk BST ceramics, which are reported to be 10–100 μC/m. Enhanced flexoelectric properties were observed from these low profile structures, suggesting advanced sensing devices can be resulted from flexoelectric structures.

The 1st flexoelectric sensor we demonstrated is strain gradient sensor. Flexoelectric micro-bar was designed and prototyped for direct measuring strain gradient information in mechanical structures. Flexoelectric strain gradient sensors (SGSs) were successfully deployed around a circular hole on a metal plate structure to capture the strain gradient due to the stress concentration. The crack location in the structure can be determined by attaching multiple SGSs onto the structure and observing the electric readouts. A theoretical algorithm for localizing the crack origin was derived based on fracture mechanics theory. Moreover, the SGS has also been implemented for the measurement of the curvature of a mechanical shell structure, which is an important indicator of the structural health.

We also, for the first time, demonstrated flexoelectric vibration sensors. A flexoelectric accelerometer was designed and prototyped using a BST cantilever structure in millimeter scale. A stable sensitivity of 0.84 pC/g was achieved over the frequency range of 100 Hz to 1.6 kHz. To enhance the device output, a multilayer structure design with serial electrical connection was proposed and experimentally characterized. A three layer prototype was demonstrated to exhibits approximately a three folds signal amplification. In addition, a flexoelectric microphone was demonstrated based on a micro-machined bridge structure. It showed a sensitivity of 0.92 pC/Pa below the resonance of 99 kHz.
